Has the patient experienced rapid and irregular palpitations? This suggests atrial fibrillation (AF).
Has the patient experienced rapid and regular palpitations, with or without dizziness, and possibly terminated by Valsalva manoeuvres? This suggests supraventricular tachycardia (SVT).
Has the patient experienced rapid and regular palpitations with dizziness, syncope, or near syncope? This suggests ventricular tachycardia (VT), especially in the context of ischemic heart disease.
Has the patient experienced syncope with bradycardia or no palpitations? This suggests heart block.
Has the patient experienced symptoms of AF and episodes of syncope? This suggests sick sinus syndrome.
Is there a family history of sudden death? This suggests the possibility of congenital long or short QT interval, Brugada syndrome, or a structural cardiac problem like hypertrophic cardiomyopathy.
Has the patient experienced any syncope in association with antiarrhythmic drug treatment? This may suggest proarrhythmia, particularly with class 1C drugs or sotalol.
